I think it's likely a first reaction here, Bryan, on the politically-correct pretext of "privacy". When a "right" to be forgotten is accurately recognized as license to have the means by which a society judges one of its members for appropriate inclusion into all its rituals and interactions, I suspect the reaction may be different.

Certainly, the reaction by the Euro-press has been pensive, as a major investigative tool soon will be badly damaged from the perspective of their needs.

But the Euros, with parliamentary systems that follow a sometimes-excessive popular will of lower houses without robust upper houses to moderate that excess, tend to go too far, until enough oxen are gored that they need to retreat. Their courts are reflective of this headlong flight into excess.

As I would expect, you understand precisely the purpose and the reaction across a broad spectrum in the EU, most especially the most important there, the top quality press are apposed to the decision and the yellow journalists, suffering from their usual lack of common sense, applaud it. Your observation on the different political traditions is spot on, and the lack of functional bicameral legislatures in some countries, such as Ireland, is an impediment. That they also lack a US style Constitution and Bill of Rights, and have little or no understanding of same and its effect in practice, along with a mixed history of censorship remains influential.

So many of the comments totally misjudge both the legal ruling and its result in practice, as does Maureen to some extent. The ruling specifically states that the link is to be removed; in other words access is restricted and blocked; there is no ruling regarding removal of the content objected to. Americans and Europeans share a common difficulty; they rarely understand each others political and cultural traditions. That legal hearings will be held in the home country of the plaintiff will add to the confusion is certain as a variety of legal standards and cultural bias is brought into play.

It is predicted that the new EU parliament, now going through its reelection cycle this week, may take up this issue and pass legislation on the matter. That debate will be interesting and will uncover prejudices and censorship bias.

There is Maureen more to the decision than you have discussed in your column. There is a long history in the 28 countries of the EU of differing standards of law, privacy, freedom of the press and that most important issue; censorship. The legal ruling requires Google, and likely all "search engines", to sever the links to information that a plaintiff may find uncomfortable, not to erase that information, which is neither required nor possible, since that information is not the property of Google.

Censorship, whether state sponsored, under which I grew up in Ireland, more than 60 years ago, which was run by a government functionary, who decided what newspapers could publish, what books we could read, what movies could be screened, and whose telephones would be tapped, was actually popular among both the public and the RCC. We the people then were thus protected from any excesses we may have been inclined to indulge in.

The court ruling makes it possible to take an eraser to the link to former indiscretions where the case will be heard in the home country of the plaintiff replete with all the cultural baggage, prejudices and contempt for freedom of expression, free speech and freedom of the press that varies from country to country.

In Europe there is neither a US style Constitution nor a First Amendment. The concept of the protection of the 44 words of the First Amendment is happily sacred to Americans and will remain so. That the US would laud this decision amazes me.

Arthur Gelb was an amazing, amazing man. I am one of countless journalists who considered Arthur a mentor. He saw -- as all great leaders do -- capabilities in those he led that we didn't yet see in ourselves. Arthur hired me at the NY Times in 1979, mostly based on the recommendation of his best friend Joseph Heller, who barely knew me but somehow convinced Arthur I was worthy.

In a burst of enthusiasm that seems incredible to me today, I invited Arthur and his wife Barbara, as well as Joe Heller and his then wife Shirley, to have dinner at the small apartment I shared with the woman I had just married, Deborah Pines.

Who knows what I was thinking to invite my soon-to-be-boss to dinner -- my already iconic boss -- before I'd worked a day at the paper? But Arthur and Barbara came, and so did Joe and Shirley, and Arthur and Joe got increasingly drunk during the evening. By 9 or 10 pm, Arthur was leaning out the window of my tiny dining room, bellowing into the night something about Abe Rosenthal, something funny and plaintive and bittersweet about the boss he loved without reservation but who tortured him endlessly.

Over my years at the Times, Arthur blithely ran interference for me (and for others he had hired) so that we all could do more of what we wanted to do on a paper which otherwise was incredibly rigid and hierarchical. He was unabashed about playing favorites, and I was so thrilled to be one of them.

(continued)
I also still remember -- four years after I joined the Times -- going to his sprawling rent-stabilizede apartment in the Apthorp on 79th and Broadway to say goodbye. I was there to tell him I was leaving the Times. He was plainly distraught, which made me feel a blend of terrible sadness and enormous pride, the latter for the fact that he cared that I was leaving.

Arthur couldn't understand for one moment why I would choose to leave -- much less to become a staff writer at New York Magazine -- or why anyone would leave the Times for that matter, because he loved it so totally and completely, even if it sometimes broke his heart.

What an amazing 90 years Arthur Gelb put in on this earth, inspiring countless young journalists, as he did me. I truly never imagined he would ever die, and I was startled to read today that he had.

I had lunch with Arthur two years ago or so, and I remember trying to convince him that what I'd chosen to do with my life since the Times was in some way comparable to the incomparable privilege of working at the Times. He didn't buy it for a minute.

I am so privileged to have known and loved this extraordinary man, and so deeply sad he is gone.

In 1960 and 61, I was a young copy editor at The Times working on the obit desk--the lowest of the low, although we did handle the critics on deadline late in our shift.  Often I had to go back to Artie Gelb to ask him something about his review.  He was nervous and revved up after writing on deadline, but he was as patient and kind to me as any newspaper person I ever knew, and that's still true, more than 50 years later.     --Stan Burroway
A true journalist is gone.  There aren't any left.
